title: 105_hr1549
content: The Act is titled the "Harold Hughes-Bill Emerson Commission on Alcoholism Act" and establishes a commission known as the Harold Hughes-Bill Emerson Commission on Alcoholism with specified duties. The Harold Hughes-Bill Emerson Commission on Alcoholism is tasked with holding public hearings, promoting national consensus on alcoholism policy issues, evaluating interest in new medications, and conducting studies in collaboration with the National Institute on Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse. The Harold Hughes-Bill Emerson Commission on Alcoholism conducts a study to identify current alcohol research needs, evaluate physician education on alcoholism, and recommend research information dissemination to prevention and treatment services. The Harold Hughes-Bill Emerson Commission on Alcoholism will make recommendations to reduce and prevent alcoholism, including appropriate roles for different levels of government and specific changes to federal laws and programs. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within two years of receiving funding, describing their findings and may also submit interim reports as needed. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within two years of receiving funding, describing their findings and may also submit interim reports as needed. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission on Alcoholism is composed of 12 voting members appointed by the President, along with ex officio voting and nonvoting members. Appointed members must come from specific fields of expertise such as economics, biomedical research, behavioral research, clinical work, and business. The Commission on Alcoholism consists of 12 members appointed by the President, including representatives from various fields like business, medical schools, and health providers. The Senate and House leaders appoint additional members, including experts in alcoholism prevention and treatment. The Commission on Alcoholism consists of 12 members appointed by the President, including representatives from various fields like business, medical schools, and health providers. The Commission includes Members of the House, individuals with personal experience with alcoholism, a marketing expert, and the Director of the National Institute on Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse as a voting ex officio member. Nonvoting ex officio members or advisors may also be requested from Federal officials. The Commission on Alcoholism consists of 12 members appointed by the President, including representatives from various fields. The Commission is chaired by a designated voting member and members serve for the duration of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission on Alcoholism consists of 12 members appointed by the President, chaired by a designated member. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Meetings are called by the Chair or majority, with a quorum of 7 members. Members do not receive compensation for their service. Members of the Commission on Alcoholism may receive reimbursement for travel and other expenses incurred while carrying out their duties, in accordance with relevant regulations. SEC. 5. STAFF AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission may appoint staff, including an executive director, without following certain federal regulations on appointments and pay rates. Staff members' compensation is limited to the maximum rate of basic pay for GS-15, with the executive director not exceeding the maximum rate for positions above GS-15. The Commission may procure consultants for temporary services under specific regulations, with compensation not exceeding the maximum rate of basic pay for positions above GS-15. Consultants may be reimbursed for necessary expenses related to their activities for the Commission. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use the United States mails, and receive administrative support services as needed to carry out its duties under section 3. The Commission has the authority to accept cash and in-kind contributions for carrying out its activities. The Commission terminates 60 days after the final report submission. $3,000,000 is authorized for this Act. Section 18 of Public Law 96-180 is repealed.
